repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
Nit: Consistent quoting.
```suggestion
    print('Could not find NVIM_API_LEVEL or NVIM_API_PRERELEASE in CMakeLists.txt')
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -64,6 +64,22 @@
     sys.exit(1)
 
 
+script_dir = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))
+cmake_file_path = os.path.join(script_dir, '..', 'CMakeLists.txt')
+with open(cmake_file_path, 'r') as cmake_file:
+    cmake_content = cmake_file.read()
+
+api_level_match = re.search(r'set\(NVIM_API_LEVEL (\d+)\)', cmake_content)
+api_prerelease_match = re.search(r'set\(NVIM_API_PRERELEASE (\w+)\)', cmake_content)
+
+if not api_level_match or not api_prerelease_match:
+    print("Could not find NVIM_API_LEVEL or NVIM_API_PRERELEASE in CMakeLists.txt")

comment_data.body: if a "." is in the `@since` value we should compare with the Nvim version rather than api-level. (Edit: this would be for Lua functions, not API functions)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -719,6 +736,11 @@ def para_as_map(parent, indent='', width=text_width - indentation, fmt_vimhelp=F
                 elif kind == 'warning':
                     text += render_node(child, text, indent=indent,
                                         width=width, fmt_vimhelp=fmt_vimhelp)
+                elif kind == 'since':
+                    since_match = re.match(r'^(\d+)', get_text(child))
+                    since = int(since_match.group(1)) if since_match else 0
+                    if since > NVIM_API_LEVEL or (since == NVIM_API_LEVEL and NVIM_API_PRERELEASE):

comment_data.body: I don't think that's a good idea. We should pick one versioning scheme and stick with it; everything else will just lead to confusion. (I don't mind which, though @bfredl preferred the API version.)

comment_data.body:
> Would picking SemVer require moving the C stuff to SemVer as well?

Yes, which would be breaking. (Originally, the API level was intended to move much more slowly than the Neovim minor version.)

comment_data.body:
> We should pick one versioning scheme and stick with it

How? The API level is versioned independently from Nvim version. Are we planning to increment API level when we add a new Lua function? I suppose that could work, though it's not our current practice.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -719,6 +736,11 @@ def para_as_map(parent, indent='', width=text_width - indentation, fmt_vimhelp=F
                 elif kind == 'warning':
                     text += render_node(child, text, indent=indent,
                                         width=width, fmt_vimhelp=fmt_vimhelp)
+                elif kind == 'since':
+                    since_match = re.match(r'^(\d+)', get_text(child))
+                    since = int(since_match.group(1)) if since_match else 0
+                    if since > NVIM_API_LEVEL or (since == NVIM_API_LEVEL and NVIM_API_PRERELEASE):

comment_data.body:
Yes, that would be the implication (in a release; we wouldn't bump twice, of course) -- in practice, not by necessity, since it may (hopefully) happen that our Lua API becomes stable enough so there may be minor releases where we don't add any new function and so don't need to bump API level.

For the record: when I say "we should pick one versioning scheme", I meant "for Lua API". @bfredl suggested (re)using the Nvim API for that, since we already have tooling and documentation in place (we tend to prefer leveraging existing stuff over reinventing the wheel, after all), but there may be a good argument for using the Neovim version instead. (E.g., one argument I just thought of is that we already use Neovim version for deprecation, so it might make sense to use it for introduction as well.)

But no matter which we pick, I think we should _not_ allow _both_ `@since 12` and `@since 0.12` **for Lua functions**. (For Nvim API functions, it's `@since 12` or nothing.)

>> one argument I just thought of is that we already use Neovim version for deprecation, so it might make sense to use it for introduction as well.

Another argument is that api-level is less familiar to most users (including plugin authors) than Nvim version.

comment_data.body: MIN_PYTHON_VERSION (defined below) is 3.6, looks like "typing" is available [since 3.5](https://docs.python.org/3/library/typing.html)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -42,6 +42,7 @@
 import collections
 import msgpack
 import logging
+from typing import Tuple

comment_regular_data.body: Pro tip: don't use (unbackticked) `@` in commit messages. Some github user will thank you.

We actually only want to use this in the docs to mark prerelease API; we don't want to clutter the docs with historical information. So if the annotation is `@since 12`, the docs should say "unstable"; if it's `@since X` for `X<12`, it shouldn't say anything.

(And the "12" comes from the `NVIM_API_LEVEL` variable in the top `CMakeLists.txt`.)

Ah that's my bad, I didn't realize it would overlap with https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25416

I was definitely about to use it the wrong way (the "usual" way) in my inlay hints PR

Just updated this one to use the CMakeLists.txt as that seemed like a good proposal. Bumping earlier doesn't seem too bad.

> if it's `@since X` for `X<12`, it shouldn't say anything.

What about for Lua/vimscript functions? Users really like https://github.com/tweekmonster/helpful.vim as a concept. Knowing when something was introduced is often useful. Although we could put this info behind a command like `K`/`gK`/etc (but that's not available in the HTML/web :help docs).

> Users really like https://github.com/tweekmonster/helpful.vim as a concept.

This is the "usual" way I was referring to (put a semver in the `@since` and users can it to manage pinned version sets and legacy support). I assumed the reason @clason proposed to remove that info was to discourage version pinning / legacy support in favor of encouraging usage of `stable` and `nightly` tags. Or at least that people who'd care about that stuff are sophisticated enough to use hover docs

FWIW this is a much less weighty decision than what version scheme to use, since it's easily reversible and shows up in the hover docs regardless

From https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25574#discussion_r1355066369 it sounds like we're aligned, so nothing is  blocking this. And we can improve it later, but meanwhile don't want this to get forgotten. 

@llllvvuu would you mind rebasing and maybe marking a couple functions to get the pattern started?

Sure, I just introduced the pattern with some examples, using the API-level instead of Nvim version.

If we merge this, all Lua reviewers will need to know that the API-level requires a bump if a Lua function is being added while `NVIM_API_PRERELEASE` is `false`. (a lazier solution could be to pre-emptively bump [after each release](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/1b57a02969870de8503f34f7014df69ae53a7f0d) instead of [waiting until the prerelease API actually gets populated](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/db8fe63a9398efd57c3ff28aa3d93e45fb70ee1a); although such a practice would create a small range of patches that look like "pre-release" despite introducing no new features).

> a lazier solution could be to pre-emptively bump [after each release](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/1b57a02969870de8503f34f7014df69ae53a7f0d) instead of [waiting until the prerelease API actually gets populated](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/db8fe63a9398efd57c3ff28aa3d93e45fb70ee1a); although such a practice would create a small range of patches that look like "pre-release" despite introducing no new features

Yes, that seems fine to me.

Yes, current development speed means that tying Lua API to Nvim API level implies tying Nvim API level to release version (meaning, increasing one means increasing the other); I think this is fine (and a two-way door; if sometime in the future things stabilize so that breaking changes are rare, a release may not need to bump anymore).

Merging this to unblock, we can continue iterating on it.

> We actually only want to use this in the docs to mark prerelease API; we don't want to clutter the docs with historical information.

@clason why? The docs don't necessarily need to be cluttered, we can render them in an uncluttered way. But attaching version info to docstrings 

Edit: I'll post a followup which will add docs, and we can discuss there.

Then we should also do this for the Nvim API. (I'm not convinced the "historic" information is useful in, say, `:h vim.diagnostic` -- but the information should absolutely remain in the annotations within `diagnostic.lua`, of course, where devs can look it up if needed or out of interest.)

> but the information should absolutely remain in the annotations within `diagnostic.lua`, of course, where devs can look it up if needed or out of interest.)

Possibly we could "calculate" it based on git history (an improved form of [helpful.vim](https://github.com/tweekmonster/helpful.vim)). That's probably more maintainable also.
